executive_summary: The industry includes contractors who install and maintain elevators, escalators, moving walkways, and other automated heavy machinery. Business is evenly spread between millwright contracting, mainly on material-handling equipment and elevator and escalator servicing. The industry generates a significant portion of its revenue from elevator installations in new multiunit residential and commercial structures and year-round demand for repair, maintenance, and modernization work. The industry's performance is heavily dependent on investment in construction, new capital equipment, and the economy's overall health.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Falling demand from nonresidential construction has been tempered by repair work
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the COVID-19 pandemic created general macroeconomic uncertainty and specifically drove down demand for office space as work from home became more common, the value of private nonresidential construction fell, taking demand for elevator installation down a level. As sentiment improved following the pandemic, nonresidential construction has returned to growth, as has industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Steady demand for maintenance and repair work
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While new elevator installations are intrinsically tied to macroeconomic conditions and ebb and flow according to residential and commercial markets, repair and maintenance work must often be addressed immediately.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Expected increase of 1.4% in 2024, as profit slid to 3.9%
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The document mentions an expected increase of 1.4% in 2024, as profit slid to 3.9%. Although the value of nonresidential construction fell overall, driving down demand, industry declines were tempered by inclines in corporate profit and private investment in manufacturing.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growth due to key construction markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Following the COVID-19 pandemic, the industry has experienced growth due to growth across key construction markets. Steady demand for maintenance and repair work supported the industry's growth trajectory in years of reduced new installation demand.

Due to the necessity of repair, maintenance contracts will continue providing an essential cushion for many elevator installers. The industry will also benefit from increased industrial activity, particularly in the Great Lakes region, aided by a rebound in the manufacturing sector. The value of private nonresidential construction will also recover and catch up to the pace of flourishing corporate profit, supporting demand for elevator installation and maintenance from the industry's largest markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Improvements in Macroeconomic Conditions Translate into Enlivened Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Expected US real estate market improvements will primarily drive industry growth as the residential, industrial, commercial, and institutional construction markets expand. These downstream markets account for nearly three-quarters of the industry's total market.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Downstream Markets Expand as Nonresidential Building Activity Picks Up Steam
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Strong growth across these downstream markets will bolster demand for installation services from building contractors. Both the value of residential and nonresidential construction markets are set to maintain a positive trajectory trough 2029, encouraging elevator installation business activity.

In the coming years, industrial production will improve as investment in heavy industrial sectors rises, boosting demand for the installation of material-handling equipment and the relocation and assembly of existing capital equipment.

Industry contractors install, repair, and maintain escalators in shopping malls and transport terminals. Continued inclines in consumer spending will propel demand from consumer markets such as retailers.

The elevator installation and service industry will continue to derive revenue growth from the repair and reconstruction of transport terminals, factories, warehouses, refineries, and infrastructure, particularly in the areas affected by hurricanes and other natural disasters.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Multifamily Housing Construction Continues to Represent a Growth Opportunity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A resurging residential building construction sector will benefit elevator installation contractors. Burgeoning multifamily housing construction will lead to rising demand from this market, as apartment buildings and condominiums typically require the installation of elevators.

The Federal Reserve has raised or maintained interest rates since 2022; high interest rates have jeopardized the residential construction market as high interest rates dissuade investment. However, over the course of the next five years, interest rates are expected to begin to be lowered, restoring the potential for demand for elevator installation from residential markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: New entrants attracted by construction activity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Along with favorable macroeconomic conditions and business expansion, increased new construction activity will continue to attract new entrants into the industry.

industry_definition: This industry comprises establishments primarily engaged in one or more of the following activities: the installation or dismantling of elevators, escalators and moving walkways; machine rigging; millwrighting; and modernization and maintenance of products installed, which includes elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, conveyor systems and automated revolving doors.
key_trends: Declines in the value of private nonresidential construction have contributing to declining industry returns. As the macroeconomic effects of the COVID-19 have begun to fade, nonresidential construction has begun to rebound.

The industry has benefitted from growing corporate profit and private investment in manufacturing following the COVID-19 pandemic. As macroeconomic conditions have improved and commercial construction activity has been restored, elevator installation has thrived.
Corporate profit has seen overall growth in the last five years, benefitting elevator installation contractors. As commercial markets
Elevator installations and services represent a significant share of revenue for the industry, high corporate profit ensures a steady stream of demand.

Stemming from disruptions during the COVID-19 pandemic, the value of both residential and nonresidential construction has slid downward. Construction activity dried up during health and safety restrictions and later residential markets were stymied by high interest rates, forcing elevator installers to navigate these speedbumps.

As demand for new elevator installations waned during the COVID-19 pandemic, repair and maintenance services picked up the slack. Steady demand for repair and maintenance work helped buoy the industry during times in which commercial and residential markets dried up.

Increased demand from municipal building construction proved to be a benefit during the COVID-19 pandemic. Demand came from both public buildings looking to become ADA compliant and healthcare institutions looking to expand, to the benefit of elevator installation contractors.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Commercial building construction represents the largest singular market for contractor services in the industry. This market segment includes the construction of office buildings; retail buildings; hotels, motels, and tourist cabins; commercial warehouses; amusement, social and recreational buildings and nonresidential farm establishments.

The residential building market is heavily focused on installing and maintaining elevator equipment in multifamily buildings. Nearly half of industry revenue generated in the housing market stems from maintenance and repair activity.

The industry fulfills demand from activity in the municipal building market, with includes work in healthcare buildings, educational buildings, and public safety buildings. Demand for elevator installation in this segment was stimulated by the introduction of regulations that requires all buildings with a second floor to have access for disabled persons.

Contractors derive a significant portion of business from the supply of services to the manufacturing and light industrial building market, particularly the installation of manufacturing equipment and the ongoing maintenance and repair of machinery.

The provision of building equipment and other machinery installation services in the nonbuilding construction market account for a relatively minuscule portion of industry revenue. The bulk of industry activity within this market is derived from work in petrochemical plants, petroleum refineries, power plants (to a lesser extent), and heavy material production facilities (to a lesser extent).

products_and_services.product_or_service: Escalator Installation, Maintenance and Repair Services
products_and_services.product_description: Activity for this segment is mainly performed in manufacturing and industrial plants or in nonbuilding industrial structures, like blast furnaces, oil refineries and power plants. An increase in private investment in manufacturing structures has led millwright contracting to expand as a share of revenue. The industry also derives revenue from escalators' installation, repair, and maintenance.

While the installation portion of this segment generally demonstrates volatility due to fluctuating demand from construction markets, the necessity of repairs and maintenance protects contractors from experiencing large fluctuations. Maintenance activities are increasingly being performed under long-term facility management contracts, stabilizing industry revenue.

Other specialist areas of industry activity include installing automated vacuum cleaning systems, mainly in hospitals, offices, and hotels; installing small-scale incinerators, particularly in hospitals and manufacturing plants. The industry includes the installation of automated doors, mainly in shopping malls and other commercial buildings. This segment has increased as heightened consumer spending has led to added demand from retailers.

The millwright and machine rigging contracting segment include installing, repairing, and maintaining various building and industrial equipment, including material-handling equipment (e.g. conveyor and storage systems) and precision machinery. Following blueprints provided by the supplier and in consultation with the machinery owner, millwright contractors are trained to install, move, and dismantle machinery and heavy equipment.

With nearly every new commercial or multistory residential building requiring an elevator, installations closely follow construction markets. This segment has been hampered by decreases in residential and nonresidential construction markets, which is sapping demand for new installations.

tier_1_suppliers: Office Stationery Wholesaling in the US
Tool & Hardware Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Printing, Paper, Food, Textile & Other Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Real Estate and Rental and Leasing in the US
Accommodation and Food Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Private investment in manufacturing structures includes new work, additions, alterations, maintenance, and repairs. Private investment depends on the need for new space, which is determined by exporting trends, usage rates and economic cycles. Increasing capital investment in manufacturing represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

Corporate profit influences a business' ability to expand operations. As corporate profit rises, companies become more willing and able to open new locations, driving demand for new commercial construction. As commercial construction of multistory buildings increases, elevator and escalator installation demand increases. Falling corporate profit poses a potential threat to the industry.

A large portion of industry revenue is derived from installing and maintaining building equipment and machinery in nonresidential buildings. This mainly includes the installation of elevators and other building machinery in multistory commercial and industrial buildings. This industry is sensitive to fluctuations in nonresidential construction.

Consumer spending significantly influences demand for businesses throughout the economy. As consumers spend more, downstream demand for goods and services rises, encouraging companies to expand and increase production. This factor drives demand for more retail, office, warehouse, and commercial building space.

Steel is one of the main material inputs of elevators, escalators, and heavy machinery. Input costs are generally passed on to the client and are included in a price quote. Higher material prices, caused by increases in the price of steel, can increase revenue for companies, as they can pass on costs and mitigate price fluctuations effectively.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region accounts for the most industry establishments, which is closely in line with the region's share of the national population. A high concentration of establishments in Florida reflects the state's highly developed residential construction market, especially its multifamily apartment building market.

The Great Lakes region accounts for a somewhat higher share of establishments than its share of the national population. The region exhibits high demand for elevator installation due to the heavy industrial base centered on Illinois, Ohio and Michigan.

The Mid-Atlantic region contains a high share of industry activity, reflecting its the concentration of large-scale apartments and offices in this region. The Mid-Atlantic contains several of America's largest metropolitan settlements (notably New York, New Jersey and Philadelphia), and therefore has substantial demand for the installation and servicing of elevators on multistory buildings.

The population density in the West region, particularly in California, where residents are generally concentrated near San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Diego, indicates that a smaller number of industry contractors grouped in these high demand areas can serve a larger share of the population than in states with low population densities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry is highly regulated. Regulations cover a range of issues like building standards, pollution controls, state-based energy compliance, and occupational health and safety issues. To operate in most states, industry contractors require licensure. Companies must also require permits for construction work.

The National Association of Elevator Contractors (NAEC) represents the interests of independent elevator contractors. NAEC promotes awareness of the latest industry standards, offers a forum for discussing technical issues and provides education update programs.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The key factors favoring ease of entry into the industry include the low capital costs of establishing a start-up and the high attrition rate among existing contractors.
Sophisticated laser, ultrasonic measuring tools and heavy positioning equipment may be necessary to compete in some industry segments (e.g. placement of precision equipment).
Still, most enterprises can compete without substantial capital outlay.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry is dominated by small regional enterprises that often compete on the basis of price.
Contractors must ensure a high quality of work to establish reputable credibility and build relationships with both buyers and suppliers.
Successful companies look to tender long-term contracts, ensuring that constant maintenance and upkeep on facilities provides contractors with a steady revenue stream.
The larger maintenance contractors can often provide clients with total facilities management of all assets by supplying a diverse range of skills.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Despite the prevalence of a select few major players, elevator installation remains a low market share industry.
The three largest players collectively accounting for more than 22.0% of total revenue in 2023.

The industry contains many small-scale contractors operating in geographic or specialized markets. The fragmented structure of this industry is evident in the annual survey of County Business Patterns published by the US Census Bureau.
Two-thirds of companies in this industry employ fewer than 20 people, while nearly half of all enterprises employ fewer than five persons.
Small nonemploying contractors carve out a niche by serving their local regions.

Geographically, there is a higher concentration of contractors in regions with a higher density of urban settlements (residential apartments). Regions with a greater concentration of manufacturing activity (e.g. the Great Lakes and Mid-Atlantic regions) also have a high concentration of enterprises.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Surges in Commodity Prices for Key Inputs Such as Steel Drive Up Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The principal construction materials purchased by industry enterprises include tools, equipment, replacement parts, lubricants, and foundation construction materials, including concrete, wood, and steel. The industry also purchases fuels for running motor vehicles, tools, and machinery. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the price for acquiring raw materials increased, making the product costlier. As commodity prices like oil and steel surged, contractors incurred added expenses that were partly offset by raising prices for consumers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The Pandemic Depletes Construction Markets and Erodes Any Potential for Profit Gains
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit fluctuates in line with investment trends into downstream construction markets, with profit changing in response to competitive pressures in the equipment installation market. Profit for elevator installation contractors decreased in 2021 due to declining demand for new installations in the commercial building and multiunit housing markets. This decline is due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to falling demand from nonresidential construction.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: WAGE COSTS INCREASE IN LINE WITH INDUSTRY GROWTH AND DEMAND FOR MORE TECHNICAL WORKERS.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Labor costs are a significant component of the cost structure of this industry. Going forward, the industry will gain more commercial and multiunit residential construction contracts, motivating companies to increase employment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The key factors favoring ease of entry into the industry include the low capital costs of establishing a start-up and the high attrition rate among existing contractors. Sophisticated laser, ultrasonic measuring tools and heavy positioning equipment may be necessary to compete in some industry segments (e.g. placement of precision equipment). Still, most enterprises can compete without substantial capital outlay.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Shifting Construction Markets Dictate the Pace at Which Elevator Installation Revenue Grows
volatility_points.volatility_description: A degree of volatility is normal for the industry as demand depends on both business and construction cycles. Strong recoveries in downstream construction markets, especially the office and multifamily building markets, have enabled revenue to widen.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatile Swings in Commodity Prices Exert Influence Over Elevator Installation Company Profit
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is influenced by volatile swings in the price of steel, a key input for industry operations.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MAINTENANCE SERVICES PICK UP THE SLACK
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Elevator installation, maintenance and repair services represent a significant share of the revenue for the industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: DEMAND FOR MILLWRIGHT AND MACHINE RIGGING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The millwright and machine rigging contracting segment include installing, repairing, and maintaining various building and industrial equipment.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or nonresidential construction markets?
FAQs.answer: Elevator installers perform work across both the residential and nonresidential construction markets; however, the nonresidential construction market generates the majority of industry demand.

FAQs.question: Does your company serve as a general contractor or third-party subcontractor on most projects?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators primarily serve as third-party subcontractors on most new projects, with most work gained through recommendations and relationships with general contractors.

FAQs.question: Does your company make use of subcontractors to save on wage costs? Roughly, what percent of revenue is consumed by wages?
FAQs.answer: The use of subcontractors is low in this industry relative to other specialist construction trade industries.

FAQs.question: Does your company typically rent or own equipment for projects?
FAQs.answer: The industry is service-oriented and relies on the skills and knowledge of individual contractors rather than the capabilities of heavy equipment; as a result, depreciation costs are low in the industry.

FAQs.question: Investment in new technology is usually fairly low among builders and contractors. How much does your company invest in new equipment annually?
FAQs.answer: Industry contractors are increasingly working with electronic and computer interfaces, with the increasing computerization of both residential and commercial buildings necessitating more sophisticated employee training and requiring an increase in technology investment.
